questions.statement: Which of the given primary taste stimuli depend on G protein-coupled receptors to depolarise the cell?
questions.label: Taste Question 1

questions.statement: Which of the given primary taste stimuli are triggered by ions in the saliva?
questions.label: Taste Question 3

questions.statement: Which cranial nerve contains sensory neurons that contribute to the gag reflex?
questions.label: Taste Question 2

questions.statement: Binding of an odorant to an odorant receptor on olfactory cells results in which of the following?
questions.label: Smell Question 1

questions.statement: What is the mechanism of smell transduction via the olfactory nerve?
questions.label: Smell Question 2

questions.statement: The membrane potential is due to:

optionsList.optionValue: Na+ diffusion in, K+ diffusion out, the Na+/K+ pump
Na+ diffusion out, K+ diffusion in, the Na+/K+ pump
Na+ diffusion out, K+ diffusion out, the Na+/K+ pump

questions.label: Neurons and the Resting Membrane Potential Question 4

questions.statement: Which part of a neuron receives information from surrounding cells?
questions.label: Neurons and the Resting Membrane Potential Question 1

questions.statement: Action potentials are transmitted along which part of a neuron?
questions.label: Neurons and the Resting Membrane Potential Question 2

questions.statement: The resting membrane potential of a mammalian neuron is:
questions.label: Neurons and the Resting Membrane Potential Question 3

questions.statement: Which of the following statements regarding action potentials is TRUE?

optionsList.optionValue: Multiple depolarising events minimises the chance of action potential generation
Reaching the subthreshold level does not stimulate the post-synaptic membrane
Reaching the subthreshold level is enough to generate an action potential
Depolarised synaptic membrane is more negative than the hyperpolarised membrane

questions.label: Post-synaptic Binding Outcomes, the Action Potential, and Saltatory Conduction Question 1

questions.statement: Which of the following would NOT be possible occurrences when signal build-up occurs?

optionsList.optionValue: They can reach action potential as a result of EPSP
They can reach action potential as a result of IPSP
An action potential will be reached if the number of EPSP > IPSP

questions.label: Post-synaptic Binding Outcomes, the Action Potential, and Saltatory Conduction Question 3

questions.statement: When is it impossible to generate an action potential?
questions.label: Post-synaptic Binding Outcomes, the Action Potential, and Saltatory Conduction Question 6

questions.statement: What happens when an IPSP is generated after EPSP?

optionsList.optionValue: The effect of the subthreshold is enhanced

questions.label: Post-synaptic Binding Outcomes, the Action Potential, and Saltatory Conduction Question 2

questions.statement: What is the term used to describe an action potential that “jumps” from one node of Ranvier to another?
questions.label: Post-synaptic Binding Outcomes, the Action Potential, and Saltatory Conduction Question 4

questions.statement: What happens when the membrane potential goes below −70 mV?

optionsList.optionValue: Potassium conductance leads to potassium equilibrium potential
Sodium conductance leads to potassium equilibrium potential

questions.label: Post-synaptic Binding Outcomes, the Action Potential, and Saltatory Conduction Question 5

questions.statement: Which of the following types of glial cells myelinate neurons in the peripheral nervous system?
questions.label: Glial Cells and the Myelin Sheath Question 1

questions.statement: Which of the following is an attribute of ependymal cells?
questions.label: Glial Cells and the Myelin Sheath Question 2

questions.statement: Which of the following statements is TRUE?

optionsList.optionValue: Connexons are ion channels connecting 2 adjacent cells, and their opening is modulated by intracellular K+ concentration
Neurotransmitter molecules are stored in vesicles in the pre-synaptic terminal
The synaptic cleft in an electrical synapse is 20–40 nm wide

questions.label: The Synapse and Neurotransmission Question 1

questions.statement: During chemical neurotransmission, Ca2+ ions are necessary for:

optionsList.optionValue: Binding the transmitter with the post-synaptic receptor
Facilitating diffusion of the transmitter to the post-synaptic membrane
Fusing the pre-synaptic vesicle with the pre-synaptic membrane, thus releasing the transmitter
Metabolising the transmitter within the pre-synaptic vesicle

questions.label: The Synapse and Neurotransmission Question 2

questions.statement: Depending on the pre-synaptic neurotransmitter released and the post-synaptic receptor activated, the post-synaptic membrane can either be depolarised or hyperpolarised. Which of the following statements is FALSE?

optionsList.optionValue: Neurotransmitter binding to metabotropic receptors causes a conformational change in pore proteins
The action of metabotropic receptors is slower than ionotropic receptors
Neurotransmitter binding to metabotropic receptors causes a conformational change, activating a signal transduction pathway
An example of an ionotropic receptor is the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor

questions.label: Neurotransmitter Receptors Question 1

questions.statement: γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is a rapidly acting neurotransmitter. You would expect the response on the post-synaptic membrane to be:

optionsList.optionValue: Excitation due to opening of chloride channels
Hyperpolarisation due to blocking of sodium channels
Hyperpolarisation due to opening of chloride channels
Excitation due to opening of sodium channels

questions.label: Neurotransmitter Receptors Question 3

questions.statement: Nicotine (mimics acetylcholine) can bind to nicotinic cholinergic receptors. You would expect the response on the post-synaptic membrane to be:

optionsList.optionValue: Excitation due to opening of chloride channels
Hyperpolarisation due to blocking of sodium channels
Hyperpolarisation due to opening of chloride channels
Excitation due to opening of sodium channels

questions.label: Neurotransmitter Receptors Question 2

questions.statement: Which of the following statements is TRUE with regard to the termination of the synaptic action at the neuromuscular junction?

optionsList.optionValue: The re-uptake of intact acetylcholine molecules into the motor neuron terminal is responsible
Diffusion of acetylcholine away from the synapse is solely responsible
Acetylcholinesterase rapidly breaks down acetylcholine into choline and acetate
Dissociation of acetylcholine from the muscarinic receptor, after binding for several seconds, is solely responsible

questions.label: The Neuromuscular Junction Question 2

questions.statement: At the neuromuscular junction, Ca2+ ions are necessary for:

optionsList.optionValue: Binding the transmitter with the post-synaptic receptor
Facilitating diffusion of the transmitter to the post-synaptic membrane
Splitting the neurotransmitter in the synaptic cleft, deactivating the transmitter
Fusing the pre-synaptic vesicle with the pre-synaptic membrane, thus releasing the transmitter
Metabolising the transmitter within the pre-synaptic vesicle

questions.label: The Neuromuscular Junction Question 1

questions.statement: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

optionsList.optionValue: The muscle fibre and neuronal cell membranes are similar because they both have a resting membrane potential
A whole muscle, such as the semitendinosus muscle, can be made to contract more forcefully by increasing the number of motor units contracting
The muscle cell membrane transmits action potentials by saltatory conduction
The shortening of a skeletal muscle during contraction is caused by the sliding together of actin and myosin filaments

questions.label: Muscle Nerve Fibres, the Muscle Stretch, and GTO Reflexes Question 1

questions.statement: Which of the following statements regarding the process of co-activation is FALSE?

optionsList.optionValue: Intrafusal fibres receive motor innervation via γ motor neurons
γ motor neurons maintain the relative length of the muscle spindle, to the main muscle during contraction and relaxation
When muscle fibres contract, the muscle spindle shortens and the rate of action potentials in the afferent fibre increases
The purpose of maintaining muscle spindle tension is so that sensory information regarding changes in muscle length can still be signalled

questions.label: Muscle Nerve Fibres, the Muscle Stretch, and GTO Reflexes Question 4

questions.statement: Which of the following statements regarding Golgi tendon organs is FALSE?

optionsList.optionValue: Golgi tendon organs are located in the muscular tendinous junctions
Goldi tendon organs provide sensory information regarding muscle stretch
Golgi tendon organs are innervated by Ib sensory afferents
Golgi tendon organs provide sensory information regarding muscle tension

questions.label: Muscle Nerve Fibres, the Muscle Stretch, and GTO Reflexes Question 5

questions.statement: What class of muscle nerve fibre associated with muscle spindles provides sensory input regarding the amount the muscle has stretched?
questions.label: Muscle Nerve Fibres, the Muscle Stretch, and GTO Reflexes Question 3

questions.statement: What class of muscle nerve fibre associated with muscle spindles fires quickly, and responds to a change in length?
questions.label: Muscle Nerve Fibres, the Muscle Stretch, and GTO Reflexes Question 2

questions.statement: Tension is sensed by the Golgi tendon organ. Which of the following statements describes what happens next?

optionsList.optionValue: Type Ib afferent is excited, synapses with an inhibitory interneuron to the α motor neuron to decrease forced output
Type Ib afferent is excited, synapses with an inhibitory interneuron to the γ motor neuron to decrease forced output
Type Ib afferent is excited, synapses with an inhibitory interneuron to the γ motor neuron to decrease forced output
Type Ib afferent is excited, synapses with an inhibitory interneuron to the α motor neuron to increase forced output

questions.label: Muscle Nerve Fibres, the Muscle Stretch, and GTO Reflexes Question 6

questions.statement: Which of the following statements best describes the pain withdrawal reflex?

optionsList.optionValue: A noxious stimulus results in inhibition of the flexor muscles and stimulation of the extensor muscles in the affected limb, and stimulation of the flexor muscles and inhibition of the extensor muscles in the contralateral limb
A noxious stimulus results in stimulation of the flexor muscles, and stimulation of the flexor muscles in the contralateral limb
The pain withdrawal reflex results in contraction of the extensor muscles of the opposite limb to a painful stimulus, and relaxation of the flexor muscles in the affected limb

A noxious stimulus results in stimulation of the flexor muscles and inhibition of the extensor muscles in the affected limb, and inhibition of the flexor muscles and stimulation of the extensor muscles in the contralateral limb

questions.label: Pain Withdrawal Reflex Question 1

questions.statement: A gross skeletal muscle belly can be instructed (by the central nervous system) to contract more forcefully by:

optionsList.optionValue: Causing more of its motor units to contract simultaneously
Increasing the amount of acetylcholine released during each neuromuscular synaptic transmission
Increasing the frequency of action potentials in the α motor neuron’s axon

questions.label: Other Reflexes and the Motor Unit Question 1

questions.label: Cutaneous Sensory Afferents Question 1

questions.label: Nociception  Question 2

questions.statement: Which of the following statements regarding secondary hyperalgesia is FALSE?

optionsList.optionValue: The area surrounding a trauma can become tender
Hypersensitivity is restricted to those nociceptors directly exposed to the injured or inflamed tissue
Secondary hyperalgesia can alter central nociceptive processing in the spinal cord

questions.label: Nociception  Question 3

questions.statement: Sensory nerve afferents can release substances that can cause pain. Which of the following substances would be the most likely to be derived from a sensory nerve?
questions.label: Nociception  Question 1

questions.statement: Which of the following processes is the cerebral cortex NOT involved in?

optionsList.optionValue: Helps provide smooth, coordinated body movement

questions.statement: Which sensory pathway does NOT pass through the thalamus?

questions.statement: A client calls because their dog is getting more and more fearful when walking in their neighbourhood, where there’s a lot of road traffic. Last week, a car back-fired noisily in the driveway, right next to the dog. What is this an example of?
questions.label: Types of Learning Question 2

questions.statement: An animal trainer forms an association between a signal and the desired response by re-enforcing when this is achieved. For example, if a dog is barking at everyone that walks past a house, the trainer might start associating the word “speak” with the act of barking, by saying it every time the behaviour occurs. They then reinforce this with a treat. What is this an example of?
questions.label: Types of Learning Question 3

questions.statement: Which of the following is NOT a feature of habituation?

optionsList.optionValue: Desensitisation is related to a decrease in synaptic connectivity between sensory and motor neurons
Strengthens the response to a potentially dangerous stimulus
Decreases the amplitude of excitatory post-synaptic potentials
Long-term habituation results in a structural change in synaptic connections (they decrease in number)

questions.label: Types of Learning Question 1

questions.statement: During short-term sensitisation of a stimulus/response pathway, which neurotransmitter is released from the axon terminal of the facilitating interneuron?
questions.label: Neurological Steps to Learning Question 1

questions.statement: Long-term sensitisation of a stimulus/response pathway will facilitate learning. Which of the following is NOT a feature of this process?

optionsList.optionValue: Increased number of action potentials along motor neurons to carry out movement

questions.label: Neurological Steps to Learning Question 2

questions.statement: Long-term memories are stored in which part of the brain?
questions.label: Neurological Steps to Learning Question 3

questions.statement: Which of the following is NOT a step in the muscle contraction process?

optionsList.optionValue: Tropomyosin covering the active site on actin
ADP molecule released during the power stroke
ATP binds to myosin causing the dissociation of the myosin head from the actin filament
Hydrolysis of ATP allows for the cocking of the myosin head
Calcium binds to troponin C, which moves tropomyosin from the active site on the actin filament

questions.statement: Which of the following statements regarding lower motor neurons is FALSE?

optionsList.optionValue: They contact skeletal muscle, leading to muscle contraction
They travel in the corticospinal tract
Their cell body is in the spinal cord

optionsList.optionValue: It receives direct input from the cerebral cortex
It modulates activity at the brainstem level

questions.statement: In which sequence does light enter and course through the eye?

optionsList.optionValue: Object – lens – aqueous humor – vitreous humor – retina
Object – air – cornea – aqueous humor – lens – vitreous humor – retina

questions.label: Pupil, Lens, and Humors Question 1

questions.statement: The structure in the eye responsible for the greatest refraction of light is the:

questions.statement: What acts as an aperture to restrict light entry into the eye?

questions.statement: In an eye that is longer than normal, how is the image focussed incorrectly?

optionsList.optionValue: Light is not bent enough, leading to the image being focussed beyond the retina
The image is split into 2 focal points, creating blurred vision at all distances
Light rays from distant objects are focussed in front of the retina

questions.label: Errors of Refraction and Depth Perception Question 1

questions.statement: Birds can tell relative distances using one eye. What method of depth perception do they use to do this?

optionsList.optionValue: Comparing the size of the image with a known object

questions.label: Errors of Refraction and Depth Perception Question 3

questions.statement: A dog with emmetropia will have:
questions.label: Errors of Refraction and Depth Perception Question 2

questions.statement: Where are specialised photoreceptor response elements located in photoreceptor cells?

questions.label: Photoreception and Signal Convergence Question 1

questions.statement: Which of the following will contribute to the hyperpolarisation of the photoreceptor membrane?
questions.label: Photoreception and Signal Convergence Question 3

questions.statement: What happens when light photons reach the retina?
questions.label: Photoreception and Signal Convergence Question 4

questions.statement: When a dog sees an object in the distance and stares at it, which of the following is NOT a component of how they process the visual information to determine what it is?

optionsList.optionValue: The colour of the object is determined by cones
Stereopsis is used to determine how far away the object is
Light rays from the object are focussed on the retina by accommodation of the lens

questions.statement: At the auditory nerve synapse level, depolarisation of the pre-synaptic membrane causes calcium influx which results in the release of which of the following substances from the synaptic vesicles?

questions.statement: Which structure senses soundwave frequency?

questions.statement: Which of the following fluids in the ear has the highest potassium concentration?

questions.statement: Which of the following occurs during rotation of the head?

optionsList.optionValue: The endolymph moves in the opposite direction of the rotation
The resting discharge rate does not change
Some of the hair cells bend in the opposite direction, causing them to depolarise
Some of the hair cells bend in the same direction, causing them to hyperpolarise
The endolymph moves in the same direction of the rotation.

questions.statement: Where are the autonomic ganglia of the parasympathetic nervous system predominantly located?

optionsList.optionValue: Within the dorsal root of the spinal cord

optionsList.optionValue: Length is not important for determining the action

questions.statement: Where are the autonomic ganglia of the sympathetic nervous system predominantly located?

optionsList.optionValue: Within the dorsal root of the spinal cord
Close to the spinal cord in the sympathetic chain

questions.statement: Which of the following is a characteristic of a reflex?

optionsList.optionValue: It does not require a stimulus to occur
Sensory information is carried into the spinal cord via the ventral root

questions.statement: Which of the following statements about grey matter is TRUE?

optionsList.optionValue: It forms the outer segment of the spinal cord
It is found in tracts and nerves

It is a site where axons are grouped together
